1. Reduction of Single-Use Plastics:
Governments can implement policies that aim to reduce single-use plastic production and consumption by encouraging the use of reusable bags, cups, and containers in public spaces, grocery stores, and restaurants.

2. Recycling and Waste Management:
Governments can collaborate with local organizations and industries to improve waste management systems that properly dispose of plastic waste.

3. Innovation and Research:
Investing and collaborating with research organizations to innovate and develop new materials that can replace plastic or make plastic biodegradable.

4. Consumer Education:
Governments and organizations can launch a public education campaign aimed to raise consumer awareness of the environmental impacts of plastic pollution

5. International agreements:
International agreements between governments and industries could set targets for reducing plastic waste, and improve monitoring and reporting of plastic waste in global waterways.

6. Infrastructure Development:
Governments can invest in improving infrastructure to develop better systems for collecting, sorting, and recycling plastic waste. 

Individuals can take personal steps to reduce their plastic waste by being mindful of their consumption habits, choosing products made from alternative materials, composting, and properly disposing of plastic waste. Collaborating between individuals and organizations will reduce plastic waste in oceans.
